akn:section.akn:heading: Restraint in arms sales to Sub-Saharan Africa

akn:content.akn:p:
§ 2773. Restraint in arms sales to Sub-Saharan Africa It is the sense of the Congress that the problems of Sub-Saharan Africa are primarily those of economic development and that United States policy should assist in limiting the development of costly military conflict in that region. Therefore, the President shall exercise restraint in selling defense articles and defense services, and in providing financing for sales of defense articles and defense services, to countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. (Pub. L. 90–629, ch. 3, § 33, Oct. 22, 1968, 82 Stat. 1325; Pub. L. 91–672, § 3, Jan. 12, 1971, 84 Stat. 2053; Pub. L. 92–226, pt. IV, § 401(c), (d), Feb. 7, 1972, 86 Stat. 32; Pub. L. 93–189, § 25(7)–(9), Dec. 17, 1973, 87 Stat. 731; Pub. L. 93–559, § 45(a)(8), Dec. 30, 1974, 88 Stat. 1815; Pub. L. 96–92, § 18, Oct. 29, 1979, 93 Stat. 709.)
